Questions: Name the five energy stores
Answers: kinetic, gravitational potential, elastic potential, thermal, chemical

Questions: Name the four ways in which energy can be transferred.
Answers: heating, waves, electric current, mechanically (by forces)

Questions: What is a system?
Answers: an object or group of objects

Questions: What is a closed system?
Answers: a system where no energy can be transferred to or from the surroundings – the total energy in the system stays the same

Questions: What is work done?
Answers: energy transferred when a force moves an object

Questions: What is the unit for energy?
Answers: joules (J)

Questions: What is one joule of work?
Answers: the work done when a force of 1 N causes an object to move 1 m in the direction of the force

Questions: Describe the energy transfer when a moving car slows down.
Answers: energy is transferred mechanically from the kinetic store of the car to the thermal store of its brakes. Some energy is dissipated to the thermal store of the surroundings

Questions: Describe the energy transfer when an electric kettle is used to heat water.
Answers: the electric current in a kettle transfers energy to the heating element’s thermal store – energy is then transferred by heating from the heating element’s thermal store to the thermal store of the water

Questions: Describe the energy transfer when a ball is fired using an elastic band.
Answers: energy is transferred mechanically from the elastic store of the elastic band to the kinetic store of the band – some energy is dissipated to the thermal store of the surroundings

Questions: Describe the energy transfer when a battery powered toy car is used.
Answers: energy is transferred electrically from the chemical store of the battery to the kinetic store of the toy car – some energy is dissipated to the thermal store of the surroundings

Questions: Describe the energy transfer when a falling apple hits the ground.
Answers: energy is transferred from the kinetic store of the apple and dissipated to the thermal store of the surroundings by sound waves

Questions: Name the unit that represents one joule transferred per second.
Answers: watt (W)

Questions: A motor is 30% efficient. What does that mean?
Answers: 30% of the energy is usefully transferred and 70% is dissipated

Questions: What does a material’s thermal conductivity tell you?
Answers: how well it conducts heat

Questions: Which materials have low thermal conductivity?
Answers: thermal insulators

Questions: Give three factors that determine the rate of thermal energy transfer through a material.
Answers: thermal conductivity of material, temperature difference, thickness of material

Questions: What factors affect the rate of heat loss from a building?
Answers: thickness of walls and roof, thermal conductivity of walls and roof, the temperature difference between the two sides of the wall/roof

Questions: Define specific heat capacity.
Answers: amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a material by 1 °C

Questions: What is a non-renewable energy resource?
Answers: will eventually run out, is not replaced at the same rate it is being used

Questions: What is a renewable energy resource?
Answers: will not run out, it is being (or can be) replaced at the same rate as which it is used

Questions: What are the main renewable and non-renewable resources available on Earth?
Answers:
renewable: solar, tidal, wave, wind, geothermal, biofuel, hydroelectric

non-renewable: coal, oil, gas, nuclear

Questions: What are the main advantages of using coal as an energy resource?
Answers: enough available to meet current demand, reliable, can control supply to match demand, cheap to extract and use

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using coal as an energy resource?
Answers: will eventually run out, releases CO2 which contributes to climate change, releases sulfur dioxide which causes acid rain

Questions: What are the main advantages of using nuclear fuel as an energy resource?
Answers: lot of energy released from a small mass, reliable, can control supply to match demand, enough fuel available to meet current demand, no polluting gases

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using nuclear fuel as an energy resource?
Answers: waste is dangerous and difficult and expensive to deal with, expensive initial set up, expensive to shut down and to run

Questions: What are the main advantages of using solar energy?
Answers: can be used in remote places, no polluting gases, no waste products, very low running cost

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using solar energy?
Answers: unreliable, cannot control supply, initial set up expensive, cannot be used on a large scale

Questions: What are the main advantages of using tidal power?
Answers: no polluting gases, no waste products, reliable, can produce large amounts of electricity, low running cost, no fuel costs

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using tidal power?
Answers: can harm marine habitats, initial set up expensive, cannot increase supply when needed, amount of energy varies on time of month, hazard for boats

Questions: What are the main advantages of using wave turbines?
Answers: no polluting gases produced, no waste products, low running cost, no fuel costs

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using wave turbines?
Answers: unreliable, dependent on weather, cannot control supply, initial set up expensive, can harm marine habitats, hazard for boats, cannot be used on a large scale

Questions: What are the main disadvantages of using wind turbines?
Answers: unreliable, dependent on weather, cannot control supply, take up lot of space, can produce noise pollution

Questions: What are the advantages and the disadvantages of using geothermal energy?
Answers:
advantages: no polluting gases, low running cost

disadvantages: initial set up expensive, available in few locations

Questions: What are the main advantages and disadvantages of using biofuels?
Answers:
advantages: can be ‘carbon neutral’, reliable

disadvantages: expensive to produce, use land/water that might be needed to grow food

Questions: What are the main advantages and disadvantages of using hydroelectric power?
Answers:
advantages: no polluting gases, no waste products, low running cost, no fuel cost, reliable, can be controlled to meet demand

disadvantages: initial set up expensive, dams can harm/destroy marine habitats

Questions: What is electric current?
Answers: rate of flow of charge

Questions: What units are charge, current, and time measured in?
Answers: coulombs (C), amperes (A), seconds (s) respectively

Questions: What is the same at all points when charge flows in a closed loop?
Answers: current

Questions: What must there be in a closed circuit so that electrical charge can flow?
Answers: source of potential difference (p.d.)

Questions: Which two factors does current depend on and what are their units?
Answers: resistance in ohms (Ω), p.d. in volts (V)

Questions: What happens to the current if the resistance is increased but the p.d. stays the same?
Answers: current decreases

Questions: What is an ohmic conductor?
Answers: conductor where current is directly proportional to the voltage so resistance is constant (at constant temperature)

Questions: What happens to the resistance of a filament lamp as its temperature increases?
Answers: resistance increases

Questions: What happens to the resistance of a thermistor as its temperature increases?
Answers: resistance decreases

Questions: What happens to the resistance of a light-dependent resistor when light intensity increases?
Answers: resistance decreases

Questions: What are the main features of a series circuit?
Answers: same current through each component, total p.d. of power supply is shared between components, total resistance of all components is the sum of the resistance of each component

Questions: What are the main features of a parallel circuit?
Answers: p.d. across each branch is the same, total current through circuit is the sum of the currents in each branch – total resistance of all resistors is less than the resistance of the smallest individual resistor

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: Why is the current provided by a cell called a direct current (d.c.)?
Answers: only flows in one direction

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is an alternating current (a.c.)?
Answers: current that repeatedly reverses direction

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What kind of current is supplied by mains electricity?
Answers: alternating current

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is the frequency and voltage of mains electricity?

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What colours are the live, neutral, and earth wires in a three-core cable?
Answers: live = brown, neutral = blue, earth = green and yellow stripes

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is the function of the live wire in a three-core cable?
Answers: carries the alternating potential difference from the supply

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is the function of the neutral wire in a three-core cable?
Answers: completes the circuit

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is the function of the earth wire in a three-core cable?
Answers: safety wire to stop the appliance becoming live

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: When is there a current in the earth wire?
Answers: when there is a fault

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: Why is the live wire dangerous?
Answers: provides a large p.d. that would cause a large current to flow through a person if they touched it

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What is the National Grid?
Answers: nationwide network of cables and transformers that link power stations to customers

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What are step-up transformers used for in the National Grid?
Answers: increase the p.d. from the power station to the transmission cables

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What are step-down transformers used for in the National Grid?
Answers: decrease the p.d. from the transmission cables to the mains supply in buildings so that it is safe to use

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: How does having a large potential difference in the transmission cables help to make the National Grid an efficient way to transfer energy?
Answers: large p.d. means a small current is needed to transfer the same amount of power, small current in the transmission cables means less electrical power is wasted due to heating

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What two things does energy transfer to an appliance depend on?
Answers: power of appliance, time it is switched on for

Topic number: Topic 2 - Electricity 02 - Electricity in the home
Questions: What are the units for power, current, potential difference, and resistance?
Answers: watts (W), amps (A), volts (V), ohms (Ω)

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: Which two quantities do you need to measure to find the density of a solid or liquid?
Answers: mass and volume

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What happens to the particles in a substance if its temperature is increased?
Answers: they move faster and the energy in their kinetic energy store increases

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: Why are changes of state physical changes?
Answers: no new substances are produced and the substance will have the same properties as before if the change is reversed

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: Why is the mass of a substance conserved when it changes state?
Answers: the number of particles does not change

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What is the internal energy of a substance?
Answers: the total kinetic energy and potential energy of all the particles in the substance

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: Why does a graph showing the change in temperature as a substance cools have a flat section when the substance is changing state?
Answers: the energy transferred during a change in state causes a change in the internal energy of the substance

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What is the name given to the energy transferred when a substance changes state?
Answers: latent heat

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What is the specific latent heat of a substance?
Answers: the energy required to change the state of one kilogram of that substance with no change in temperature

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What is the specific latent heat of fusion a substance?
Answers: the energy required to change one kilogram of the substance from solid to liquid at its melting point, without changing its temperature

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What is the specific latent heat of vaporisation of a substance?
Answers: the energy required to change one kilogram of the substance from liquid to vapour at its boiling point, without changing its temperature

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: On a graph of temperature against time for a substance being heated up or cooled down, what do the flat (horizontal) sections show?
Answers: the time when the substance is changing state and the temperature is not changing

Topic number: Topic 3 - Particle Model of Matter - Molecules and matter
Questions: What property of a gas is related to the average kinetic energy of its particles?
Answers: temperature

Questions: Describe the basic structure of an atom.
Answers: nucleus containing protons and neutrons, around which electrons orbit in fixed energy levels/shells

Questions: Describe the plum pudding model of the atom.
Answers: sphere of positive charge with negative electrons embedded in it

Questions: What charges do protons, neutrons, and electrons carry?
Answers: protons = positive, neutrons = no charge, electrons = negative

Questions: Why do atoms have no overall charge?
Answers: equal numbers of positive protons and negative electrons

Questions: What is the radius of an atom?
Answers: around 1×10−10 m

Questions: What is ionisation?
Answers: process which adds or removes electrons from an atom

Questions: What is the mass number of an element?
Answers: number of protons + number of neutrons

Questions: Which particle do atoms of the same element always have the same number of?
Answers: protons

Questions: What are isotopes?
Answers: atoms of the same element (same number of protons) with different numbers of neutrons

Questions: What were the two main conclusions from the alpha particle scattering experiment?
Answers:
• most of the mass of an atom is concentrated in the nucleus

• nucleus is positively charged

Questions: What are the three types of nuclear radiation?
Answers: alpha, beta, and gamma

Questions: Which type of nuclear radiation is the most ionising?
Answers: alpha

Questions: What is the range in air of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation?
Answers: a few cm, 1 m, and unlimited, respectively

Questions: What are the equation symbols for alpha and beta particles?
Answers: 4/2 α and 0/−1 β

Questions: What is meant by the half-life of a radioactive source?
Answers: time taken for half the unstable nuclei to decay or the time taken for the count rate to halve

Questions: What is a scalar quantity?
Answers: only has a size (magnitude)

Questions: What is a vector quantity?
Answers: has both a size and direction

Questions: What is a force?
Answers: a push or pull that acts on an object due to the interaction with another object

Questions: Is force a vector or scalar quantity?
Answers: vector

Questions: What is a contact force?
Answers: when objects are physically touching (e.g., friction, air-resistance, tension, normal contact force)

Questions: What is a non-contact force?
Answers: when objects are physically separated (e.g., gravitational, electrostatic, magnetic)

Questions: What is the same about the interaction pair of forces when two objects interact with each other?
Answers: the forces are the same size

Questions: What is different about the interaction pair of forces when two objects interact with each other?
Answers: forces are in opposite directions

Questions: What is the size of the resultant force on an object if the forces on it are balanced?
Answers: zero

Questions: What is the centre of mass?
Answers: the point through which the weight of an object can be considered to act

Questions: What can you say about clockwise and anticlockwise moments on a balanced object?
Answers: sum of all the clockwise moments about any point = sum of all the anticlockwise moments about that point

Questions: What does Newton’s First Law say?
Answers: the velocity of an object will only change if a resultant force is acting on it

Questions: What is the resultant force on a stationary object?
Answers: zero

Questions: What is the resultant force on an object moving at a steady speed in a straight line?
Answers: zero

Questions: What does Newton’s Third Law say?
Answers: when two objects interact they exert equal and opposite forces on each other

Questions: How do you find the speed from a distance-time graph if the object is accelerating?
Answers: Draw a tangent to the curve and find the gradient.

Questions: What is the difference between speed and velocity?
Answers: speed is a scalar quantity and only has a magnitude (size), velocity is a vector quantity and has both magnitude and direction

Questions: What factors can affect the speed at which someone walks, runs, or cycles?
Answers: age, fitness, terrain, and distance travelled

Questions: What are typical speeds for a person walking, running, and cycling?
Answers: 1.5 m/s, 3.0 m/s, and 6.0 m/s respectively

Questions: What are typical speeds of a car and a train?
Answers: 13–30 m/s and 50 m/s respectively

Questions: What is a typical speed for sound travelling in air?
What is acceleration?
Answers: change in velocity of an object per second

Questions: What is the unit of acceleration?
Answers: m/s2

Questions: How can an object be accelerating even if it is travelling at a steady speed?
Answers: if it is changing direction

Questions: What is happening to an object if it has a negative acceleration?
Answers: it is slowing down

Questions: What information does the gradient of the line in a distance–time graph provide?
Answers: speed

Questions: What information does the gradient of the line in a velocity–time graph provide?
Answers: acceleration

Questions: How can the distance travelled by an object be found from its velocity–time graph?
Answers: calculate the area under the graph

Questions: What is the name given to the distance a vehicle travels to safely come to a stop after the driver has spotted a hazard?
Answers: stopping distance

Questions: What is thinking distance?
Answers: the distance vehicle travels during driver’s reaction time

Questions: What is braking distance?
Answers: the distance vehicle travels once brakes have been applied

Questions: What is the relationship between stopping distance, thinking distance, and braking distance?
Answers: stopping distance = thinking distance + braking distance

Questions: Does the speed of a vehicle have a bigger effect on braking distance or thinking distance?
Answers: braking distance

Questions: Which distance is proportional to the speed of the vehicle?
Answers: thinking distance

Questions: What are three factors that can affect the braking distance of a vehicle?
Answers: speed, road conditions, condition of tyres and brakes

Questions: What can happen if the braking force used to stop a vehicle is very large?
Answers: brakes may overheat  / the car may skid

Questions: What is elastic deformation?
Answers: an object can go back to its original shape and size when deforming forces are removed

Questions: What is inelastic deformation?
Answers: an object does not go back to its original shape and size when deforming forces are removed

Questions: How do you find the spring constant from a force-extension graph of a spring?
Answers: find the gradient of the straight line section

Questions: What is a transverse wave?
Answers: oscillations/vibrations are perpendicular (at right angles) to the direction of energy transfer

Questions: What is a longitudinal wave?
Answers: oscillations/vibrations are parallel to the direction of energy transfer

Questions: Give an example of a transverse wave.
Answers: electromagnetic waves

Questions: Give an example of a longitudinal wave.
Answers: sound waves

Questions: What is a compression?
Answers: area in longitudinal waves where the particles are squashed closer together

Questions: What is a rarefaction?
Answers: area in longitudinal waves where the particles are pulled further apart

Questions: What is the amplitude of a wave?
Answers: maximum displacement of a point on the wave from its undisturbed position

Questions: What is the wavelength of a wave?
Answers: distance from a point on one wave to the equivalent point on the adjacent wave

Questions: What is the frequency of a wave?
Answers: number of waves passing a fixed point per second

Questions: What unit is frequency measured in?
Answers: hertz (Hz)

Questions: What property of a wave always stays the same when it travels from one medium to another?
Answers: frequency

Questions: What rule do waves follow when they reflect off a surface?
Answers: angle of incidence = angle of reflection

Questions: What happens when waves are transmitted at a boundary between two substances?
Answers: they carry on moving at a different speed

Questions: What happens when waves are absorbed by a substance?
Answers: energy of the wave is transferred to energy stores of the substance

Questions: Are electromagnetic (EM) waves longitudinal or transverse waves?
Answers: transverse

Questions: Explain why EM waves are not mechanical waves.
Answers: they can travel through a vacuum (don’t need a substance to travel through)

Questions: What do EM waves transfer from their source to an absorber?
Answers: energy

Questions: List the different types of waves in the EM spectrum in order of decreasing wavelength (increasing frequency).
Answers: radio, microwave, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma

Questions: Which part of the EM spectrum can humans see?
Answers: visible light

Questions: How can electromagnetic waves be produced?
Answers: changes inside an atom/atomic nucleus

Questions: How are gamma rays produced?
Answers: changes in the nucleus of an atom, for example during radioactive decay

Questions: How can radio waves be produced?
Answers: oscillations in an electrical circuit

Questions: How can we detect radio waves?
Answers: waves are absorbed and create an alternating current with the same frequency as the radio wave

Questions: What are radio waves used for?
Answers: transmitting television, mobile phone, and Bluetooth signals

Questions: What are microwaves used for?
Answers: satellite communications, cooking food

Questions: What is infrared radiation used for?
Answers: heating, remote controls, infrared cameras, cooking food

Questions: Which types of EM waves are harmful to the human body?
Answers: ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays

Questions: What are the hazards of being exposed to ultraviolet radiation?
Answers: damage skin cells, sunburn, increase risk of skin cancer, age skin prematurely, blindness

Questions: Why are X-rays used for medical imaging?
Answers: they pass through flesh but not bone

Questions: Why are gamma rays used for treating cancer and sterilising medical equipment?
Answers: high doses kill cells and bacteria

Questions: What is a magnetic field?
Answers: the region of space around a magnet where a magnetic material will experience a force

Questions: What happens when like and unlike poles are brought together?
Answers: like = repel, unlike = attract

Questions: What happens to the strength of the magnetic field as you get further away from the magnet?
Answers: decreases

Questions: Where is the magnetic field of a magnet strongest?
Answers: at the poles

Questions: In which direction do magnetic field lines always point?
Answers: north to south

Questions: What does the distance between magnetic field lines indicate?
Answers: strength of the field, closer together = stronger field

Questions: What is a permanent magnet?
Answers: material that produces its own magnetic field

Questions: What is an induced magnet?
Answers: material that becomes magnetic when it is put in a magnetic field

Questions: What does a magnetic compass contain?
Answers: small bar magnet

Questions: What is produced around a wire when an electric current flows through it?
Answers: magnetic field

Questions: What factors does the strength of the magnetic field around a straight wire depend upon?
Answers: size of current, distance from wire

Questions: What effect does shaping the wire into a solenoid have on the magnetic field strength?
Answers: increases strength of magnetic field

Questions: How can the strength of the magnetic field inside a solenoid be increased?
Answers: put an iron core inside

Questions: What does Fleming’s left-hand rule show?
Answers: relative orientation of the force, current in the conductor, and magnetic field for the motor effect

Questions: What is the symbol for magnetic flux density and what unit is it measured in?
Answers: B, tesla (T)

Questions: What is the motor effect?
Answers: when a conductor placed in a magnetic field experiences a force

Questions: What causes the motor effect?
Answers: interaction between the magnetic field created by current in a wire and the magnetic field in which the wire is placed

Questions: What do loudspeakers and headphones do?
Answers: use the motor effect to convert variations in current in electrical circuits to pressure variations in sound waves
